Watts are a measure of power (energy over time) not energy. Energy is measured in Joules. Neither Amperage (amps) nor voltage (volts) is a measure of energy, with amps being the measure of current and volts the difference in electrical charge. If you want the energy of the electric current then you multiply volts time amps times time. We can be exposed to currents of incredibly high amperage OR voltage and be fine as long as one of the two is low. With high amps as long as the voltage is below the electric breakdown point of our skin you can have as high amps as you want till the heat from the resistance of the wire kills you (theoretically infinite amps possible if through a superconductor). If you have decent voltage and high amps then your heart will stop and you will become rigid as all your muscels are activated by the current until you die from loss of oxygenated blood flow to your brain, unless you have really high amps in which case you would fry like a squirrel on a transformer before anoxia does you in.

This channel, although it does state several true facts, tends to misrepresentat or misapply certain ideas and concepts, but on the whole it does provide education on a basic level for many topics.

TLDR: This is a pretty good channel, but there are some factual errors in the videos.

This video needs to use consistent units. Energy is not measured in Watts. A Watt has nothing to do with electricity. A Watt is a unit of power, and power is defined as the amount of work done divided by the amount of time it takes to do that work. When you get your electricity bill, you are charged for a unit called "kilowatt hours", which means power multiplied by time, so you end up with an amount of work, which is measured in Joules. The reason Kilowatt hours are used and not joules is because 1 kilowatt hour is equal to 3,600,000 joules.

I'm a big fan of alternative energy but the wind turbine effect on hurricanes is most likely opposite and would have other not intended consequences. It is a very complex equation but it all comes down to how a heat engine functions and energy balance. A couple factors to consider if we set a large farm on the gulf coast energy would be removed from wind but this would also slow the amount of warmth and moisture reaching the midwest. This then increases the delta T between the gulf and areas north this would result in greater winds. This is a simplified view other factors are ocean temp changes causing ocean current changes also it's a global system. But bottom line anyway is whenever energy is taken from one source to another there will be changes.

It probably would have served the video well to give a quick rundown on what voltage and current are, and how they affect electrocution potential.

A good analogy that helped me learn was to compare an electrical wire to a water pipe, where the voltage is the water pressure and the current is how much the water is flowing, as a result of how much resistance there is. Resistance would be how wide the pipe is and/or how open the faucet is. The more you open the faucet (reduce the resistance), the more the current increases, which means more water coming out. If the water pressure (voltage) is low, then it doesn't come out very hard or fast, but if it's high, then it blasts out. Conversely, if the pressure is high, but the faucet isn't open very much, then the current is low and you don't get much water. But what you do get will be shooting out quite hard (hurts to put your finger in front of it).

So high voltage, low current is dangerous, if it's applied in the wrong place (your heart). But if it just shoots through your body without hitting your heart, then you'd likely survive with minimal injury. It'll sting, though.
Low voltage, high current can be dangerous, depending on how low the voltage is. The danger with low voltage is that it travels slower (like low water pressure), so it will stay in your body for longer and can do more damage that way. If it hits your heart, you might be killed, unless the voltage is so low that it doesn't have the power to interrupt your heart beat. It's less painful too. Low voltage feels like a buzz, like when you lick a 9V battery. In that way, it can be more dangerous, because you won't have as much of an instinct to stop it.
High voltage, high current is the obviously the most deadly. A lot of voltage entering your body at high current will likely burn you to a crisp. Lightning is high voltage, high current, but the saving grace for lightning is that it's quick. You just get one quick burst of it. Contrary to if you put your hands on an open wire with high voltage and high current, then it'll just keep coming until you look like you shook hands with the Joker.

@AsapSCIENCE Be careful, a Watt isn't a unit of energy, its a unit of power. Note that power P = dE/dt; i.e that power is the time derivative of energy, and one watt is a joule per unit second. This is why your energy bill is measured in kilowatt hours, i.e a product of the amount of power you use and how long you use it for. Actually:
 2 mA - we feel electrical current passing through our body 
 7-9 mA  - passing electrical current causes muscle spasm  
 19 mA - passing electrical current causes very strong spasm,we can't let off "source" of electric energy that causes spasm 
 48 mA - passing electrical current = deadly   
Have in mind that these numbers variate from lots of factors like :  
your electrical resistance,path of current through your body,...

Also when current flows through you,most endangered organs are : 
heart & brain.Nervous system is also in danger.

Speaking in voltages :  
-Dry environment :  
50 Volts is deadly for human (AC).  
120 Volts is deadly for human (DC).  
-Wet environment :  
24 Volts is deadly for human (AC).  
60 Volts is deadly for human (DC).  
 

Basically after you take a bath your resistance is equal to 500 Ohms .    

U=Rh*I=500 Ohms*48 mA = 24 Volts  

U-Voltage (enough to kill you after bath)  
Rh-Your electrical resistance after bath
I - deadly electrical current for humans

As a physics teacher, the bit around 2:00 bothers me.
Not because it's wrong, but because it blurs the distnction between voltage and current.

Moments earlier, the video states that 7mA of current can kill: correct
Then it states that 1GV will kill: also correct

The trouble is, it's confusing, or muddling, or messing somehow with the 2 concepts. It implies that low current is trumped by high voltage.

Wind turbines cost around 1000 euro's per person in the Netherlands, whilst the amount of energy it would produce would only add up to a VERY TINY amount of the total energy usage of our country.

Simply put: It's not worth it.

What does work though is putting that 1000 euro's into insulation for your house, what's better than producing more energy? Using less. If you have a household of 3 people that would add up to 1000 euro's per house, and you can do a lot of insulation for 3000 euro's.

The government can ask for tax on energy though, not on using it less.

For those of you ignorant (looking at you @Gytax0):  A food Calorie is a measurement of a KiloCalorie (kcal) of energy (or 4187 Joules).  Which by measurement of metric is 1000 calories of energy.   Food calories and the metric value of energy "calorie (cal)" are two DIFFERENT things.    Food Calorie = 1 kcal.  The more you know.
